1"""For polynomial fitting propagation, using approximations of 1st or 2nd order 

2terms but ignoring some spherical effects. 

3 

4Although this could be easily implemented in a better method using subclassing 

5rather than having two classes, as having a 3rd order is not really feasible,  

6and for the sake of readability and stability, two separate copy-like classes 

7are written. 

8""" 

9 

10import numpy as np 

11import scipy as sp 

12import scipy.optimize as sp_optimize 

13 

14import opihiexarata.library as library 

15import opihiexarata.library.error as error 

16import opihiexarata.library.hint as hint 

17 

18 

19class LinearPropagationEngine(library.engine.PropagationEngine): 

20 """A simple propagation engine which uses 1st order extrapolation of 

21 RA DEC points independently to determine future location. 

22 

23 Attributes 

24 ---------- 

25 ra_array : ndarray 

26 The array of right ascension measurements to extrapolate to. 

27 dec_array : ndarray 

28 The array of declinations measurements to extrapolate to. 

29 obs_time_array : ndarray 

30 The array of observation times which the RA and DEC measurements were 

31 taken at. The values are in Julian days. 

32 ra_poly_param : tuple 

33 The polynomial fit parameters for the RA(time) propagation. 

34 dec_poly_param : tuple 

35 The polynomial fit parameters for the DEC(time) propagation. 

36 """ 

37 

38 def __init__(self, ra: hint.array, dec: hint.array, obs_time: hint.array) -> None: 

39 """Instantiation of the propagation engine. 

40 

41 Parameters 

42 ---------- 

43 ra : array-like 

44 An array of right ascensions to fit and extrapolate to, must be in 

45 degrees. 

46 dec : array-like 

47 An array of declinations to fit and extrapolate to, must be in 

48 degrees. 

49 obs_time : array-like 

50 An array of observation times which the RA and DEC measurements 

51 were taken at. This should be in Julian days. 

52 

53 Returns 

54 ------- 

55 None 

56 """ 

57 # Must be parallel arrays. 

58 ra = np.asarray(ra) 

59 dec = np.asarray(dec) 

60 obs_time = np.asarray(obs_time) 

61 if ra.shape == dec.shape == obs_time.shape: 

62 # This is expected. 

63 pass 

64 else: 

65 raise error.InputError( 

66 "The RA, DEC, and observation time arrays should be parallel and be" 

67 " flat. They represent the observations of asteroids." 

68 ) 

69 

70 # Saving the observational values. The UNIX time is helpful for fitting 

71 # to avoid numerical issues with using Julian days.s 

72 self.ra_array = ra 

73 self.dec_array = dec 

74 self.unix_obs_time_array = library.conversion.julian_day_to_unix_time( 

75 jd=obs_time 

76 ) 

77 self.obs_time_array = obs_time 

78 

79 # Computing the fitting parameters. That is, the polynomial fit of both 

80 # RA and DEC as a function of time. 

81 ra_param, __ = self.__fit_polynomial_function( 

82 fit_x=self.unix_obs_time_array, fit_y=self.ra_array 

83 ) 

84 dec_param, __ = self.__fit_polynomial_function( 

85 fit_x=self.unix_obs_time_array, fit_y=self.dec_array 

86 ) 

87 self.ra_poly_param = ra_param 

88 self.dec_poly_param = dec_param 

89 

90 # All done. 

91 return None 

92 

93 @staticmethod 

94 def __linear_function( 

95 x: hint.array, 

96 c0: float, 

97 c1: float, 

98 ) -> hint.array: 

99 """The linear polynomial function that will be used. 

100 

101 This function is hard coded to be a specific order on purpose. The 

102 order may be changed between versions if need be, but should not be 

103 changed via configuration. 

104 

105 Parameters 

106 ---------- 

107 x : array-like 

108 The input for computing the polynomial. 

109 c0 : float 

110 Coefficient for order 0. 

111 c1 : float 

112 Coefficient for order 1. 

113 

114 Returns 

115 ------- 

116 y : array-like 

117 The output after computing the polynomial with the provided 

118 coefficients. 

119 """ 

120 # Computing the polynomial 

121 y = c0 + c1 * x**1 

122 return y 

123 

124 def __fit_polynomial_function( 

125 self, fit_x: hint.array, fit_y: hint.array 

126 ) -> tuple[tuple, tuple]: 

127 """A wrapper class for fitting the defined specific polynomial function. 

128 

129 Parameters 

130 ---------- 

131 fix_x : array-like 

132 The x values which shall be fit. 

133 fix_y : array-like 

134 The y values which shall be fit. 

135 

136 Returns 

137 ------- 

138 fit_param : tuple 

139 The parameters of the polynomial that corresponded to the best fit. 

140 Determined by the order of the polynomial function. 

141 fit_error : tuple 

142 The error on the parameters of the fit. 

143 """ 

144 # Ensuring that the arrays are numpy-like and can thus be handled by 

145 # scipy. 

146 fit_x = np.asarray(fit_x) 

147 fit_y = np.asarray(fit_y) 

148 # Fitting. 

149 polynomial_function = self.__linear_function 

150 max_iteration_count = int(1e6) 

151 try: 

152 # Most efficient method, but might fail with too few observations. 

153 fit_param, fit_covar = sp_optimize.curve_fit( 

154 polynomial_function, 

155 fit_x, 

156 fit_y, 

157 method="lm", 

158 ) 

159 except: 

160 fit_param, fit_covar = sp_optimize.curve_fit( 

161 polynomial_function, 

162 fit_x, 

163 fit_y, 

164 method="trf", 

165 max_nfev=max_iteration_count, 

166 ) 

167 # Error on the fit itself. 

168 fit_error = np.sqrt(np.diag(fit_covar)) 

169 # All done. 

170 return fit_param, fit_error 

171 

172 def forward_propagate( 

173 self, future_time: hint.array 

174 ) -> tuple[hint.array, hint.array]: 

175 """Determine a new location(s) based on the polynomial propagation, 

176 providing new times to locate in the future. 

177 

178 Parameters 

179 ---------- 

180 future_time : array-like 

181 The set of future times which to derive new RA and DEC coordinates. 

182 The time must be in Julian days. 

183 

184 Returns 

185 ------- 

186 future_ra : ndarray 

187 The set of right ascensions that corresponds to the future times, 

188 in degrees. 

189 future_dec : ndarray 

190 The set of declinations that corresponds to the future times, in 

191 degrees. 

192 """ 

193 # As the polynomial fitting was done with UNIX time instead of Julian 

194 # days, we need to convert to the same timescale. 

195 future_time_unix = library.conversion.julian_day_to_unix_time(jd=future_time) 

196 # Determining the RA and DEC via the polynomial function based on the 

197 # fitted parameters. 

198 new_ra = self.__linear_function(future_time_unix, *self.ra_poly_param) 

199 new_dec = self.__linear_function(future_time_unix, *self.dec_poly_param) 

200 # Apply wrap around for the angles. 

201 future_ra = (new_ra + 360) % 360 

202 future_dec = np.abs(((new_dec - 90) % 360) - 180) - 90 

203 return future_ra, future_dec 

204 

205 

206class QuadraticPropagationEngine(library.engine.PropagationEngine): 

207 """A simple propagation engine which uses 2nd order extrapolation of 

208 RA DEC points independently to determine future location. 

209 

210 Attributes 

211 ---------- 

212 ra_array : ndarray 

213 The array of right ascension measurements to extrapolate to. 

214 dec_array : ndarray 

215 The array of declinations measurements to extrapolate to. 

216 obs_time_array : ndarray 

217 The array of observation times which the RA and DEC measurements were 

218 taken at. The values are in Julian days. 

219 ra_poly_param : tuple 

220 The polynomial fit parameters for the RA(time) propagation. 

221 dec_poly_param : tuple 

222 The polynomial fit parameters for the DEC(time) propagation. 

223 """ 

224 

225 def __init__(self, ra: hint.array, dec: hint.array, obs_time: hint.array) -> None: 

226 """Instantiation of the propagation engine. 

227 

228 Parameters 

229 ---------- 

230 ra : array-like 

231 An array of right ascensions to fit and extrapolate to, must be in 

232 degrees. 

233 dec : array-like 

234 An array of declinations to fit and extrapolate to, must be in 

235 degrees. 

236 obs_time : array-like 

237 An array of observation times which the RA and DEC measurements 

238 were taken at. This should be in Julian days. 

239 

240 Returns 

241 ------- 

242 None 

243 """ 

244 # Must be parallel arrays. 

245 ra = np.asarray(ra) 

246 dec = np.asarray(dec) 

247 obs_time = np.asarray(obs_time) 

248 if ra.shape == dec.shape == obs_time.shape: 

249 # This is expected. 

250 pass 

251 else: 

252 raise error.InputError( 

253 "The RA, DEC, and observation time arrays should be parallel and be" 

254 " flat. They represent the observations of asteroids." 

255 ) 

256 

257 # Saving the observational values. The UNIX time is helpful for fitting 

258 # to avoid numerical issues with using Julian days. 

259 self.ra_array = ra 

260 self.dec_array = dec 

261 self.unix_obs_time_array = library.conversion.julian_day_to_unix_time( 

262 jd=obs_time 

263 ) 

264 self.obs_time_array = obs_time 

265 

266 # Computing the fitting parameters. That is, the polynomial fit of both 

267 # RA and DEC as a function of time. 

268 ra_param, __ = self.__fit_polynomial_function( 

269 fit_x=self.unix_obs_time_array, fit_y=self.ra_array 

270 ) 

271 dec_param, __ = self.__fit_polynomial_function( 

272 fit_x=self.unix_obs_time_array, fit_y=self.dec_array 

273 ) 

274 self.ra_poly_param = ra_param 

275 self.dec_poly_param = dec_param 

276 

277 # All done. 

278 return None 

279 

280 @staticmethod 

281 def __quadratic_function( 

282 x: hint.array, c0: float, c1: float, c2: float 

283 ) -> hint.array: 

284 """The polynomial function that will be used. 

285 

286 This function is hard coded to be a specific order on purpose. The 

287 order may be changed between versions if need be, but should not be 

288 changed via configuration. 

289 

290 Parameters 

291 ---------- 

292 x : array-like 

293 The input for computing the polynomial. 

294 c0 : float 

295 Coefficient for order 0. 

296 c1 : float 

297 Coefficient for order 1. 

298 c2 : float 

299 Coefficient for order 2. 

300 

301 Returns 

302 ------- 

303 y : array-like 

304 The output after computing the polynomial with the provided 

305 coefficients. 

306 """ 

307 # Computing the polynomial 

308 y = c0 + c1 * x**1 + c2 * x**2 

309 return y 

310 

311 def __fit_polynomial_function( 

312 self, fit_x: hint.array, fit_y: hint.array 

313 ) -> tuple[tuple, tuple]: 

314 """A wrapper class for fitting the defined specific polynomial function. 

315 

316 Parameters 

317 ---------- 

318 fix_x : array-like 

319 The x values which shall be fit. 

320 fix_y : array-like 

321 The y values which shall be fit. 

322 

323 Returns 

324 ------- 

325 fit_param : tuple 

326 The parameters of the polynomial that corresponded to the best fit. 

327 Determined by the order of the polynomial function. 

328 fit_error : tuple 

329 The error on the parameters of the fit. 

330 """ 

331 # Ensuring that the arrays are numpy-like and can thus be handled by 

332 # scipy. 

333 fit_x = np.asarray(fit_x) 

334 fit_y = np.asarray(fit_y) 

335 # Fitting. 

336 polynomial_function = self.__quadratic_function 

337 try: 

338 # Most efficient method, but might fail with too few observations. 

339 fit_param, fit_covar = sp_optimize.curve_fit( 

340 polynomial_function, 

341 fit_x, 

342 fit_y, 

343 method="lm", 

344 p0=[1, 1, 0], 

345 max_nfev=10000, 

346 ) 

347 except: 

348 fit_param, fit_covar = sp_optimize.curve_fit( 

349 polynomial_function, 

350 fit_x, 

351 fit_y, 

352 method="trf", 

353 p0=[1, 1, 0], 

354 max_nfev=10000, 

355 ) 

356 # Error on the fit itself. 

357 fit_error = np.sqrt(np.diag(fit_covar)) 

358 # All done. 

359 return fit_param, fit_error 

360 

361 def forward_propagate( 

362 self, future_time: hint.array 

363 ) -> tuple[hint.array, hint.array]: 

364 """Determine a new location(s) based on the polynomial propagation, 

365 providing new times to locate in the future. 

366 

367 Parameters 

368 ---------- 

369 future_time : array-like 

370 The set of future times which to derive new RA and DEC coordinates. 

371 The time must be in Julian days. 

372 

373 Returns 

374 ------- 

375 future_ra : ndarray 

376 The set of right ascensions that corresponds to the future times, 

377 in degrees. 

378 future_dec : ndarray 

379 The set of declinations that corresponds to the future times, in 

380 degrees. 

381 """ 

382 # As the polynomial fitting was done with UNIX time instead of Julian 

383 # days, we need to convert to the same timescale. 

384 future_time_unix = library.conversion.julian_day_to_unix_time(jd=future_time) 

385 # Determining the RA and DEC via the polynomial function based on the 

386 # fitted parameters. 

387 new_ra = self.__quadratic_function(future_time, *self.ra_poly_param) 

388 new_dec = self.__quadratic_function(future_time, *self.dec_poly_param) 

389 # Apply wrap around for the angles. 

390 future_ra = (new_ra + 360) % 360 

391 future_dec = np.abs(((new_dec - 90) % 360) - 180) - 90 

392 return future_ra, future_dec
